dictionary.phrase: split something between (someone and someone else)
dictionary.definition: to divide something between two people or things. The cook split the last of the pie between Jane and Carla.  We have to split the copies of the reports between the two committees.

dictionary.phrase: split something between (something and something else)
dictionary.definition: to divide something between two people or things. The cook split the last of the pie between Jane and Carla.  We have to split the copies of the reports between the two committees.
to sever connection with something; to separate from something. (Of is usually retained before pronouns.) _ Dave split a piece of wood off the log to use for kindling.  He split off a stick of wood.
to sever connection with something; to separate from something. (Of is usually retained before pronouns.) _ Dave split a piece of wood off the log to use for kindling.  He split off a stick of wood.

dictionary.phrase: sponge something off of someone or something
dictionary.definition: to beg or borrow money or food from someone or a group. Please stop sponging food and money off your relatives! _ Stop sponging off food and money all the time!
to beg or borrow money or food from someone or a group. Please stop sponging food and money off your relatives! _ Stop sponging off food and money all the time!

to slouch or lounge somewhere; to spread oneself out casually while lounging. (Usually refers to habitual action, perhaps in a number of places.) _ He sprawled about, loafing the afternoon away.  When I came into the room, four teenage boys were sprawled around the furniture, watching television.

dictionary.phrase: spray something onto someone or something
dictionary.definition: to direct a mist or stream of a liquid onto someone or something.  Danny sprayed cold water onto the boys and cooled them off.  Dan sprayed on some cold water.  I sprayed the paint on and it dried almost immediately.

to direct a mist or stream of a liquid onto someone or something.  Danny sprayed cold water onto the boys and cooled them off.  Dan sprayed on some cold water.  I sprayed the paint on and it dried almost immediately.
to distribute a coating of something onto something. Spread the butter onto the bread evenly. Spread on the butter evenly.  Donna spread the paint on with a roller.
to distribute a coating of something onto something. Spread the butter onto the bread evenly. Spread on the butter evenly.  Donna spread the paint on with a roller.
Sl. to treat someone by buying something.  I’m bouncing for pizza. Any takers? _ Ralph sprang for drinks, and we all had a great time.
Sl. to treat someone by buying something.  I’m bouncing for pizza. Any takers? _ Ralph sprang for drinks, and we all had a great time.

dictionary.phrase: sprinkle something on(to) someone or something
dictionary.definition: to scatter or dribble something onto someone or something. The minister sprinkled the water onto the baby.  The cook sprinkled on a dusting of powdered sugar.
to scatter or dribble something onto someone or something. The minister sprinkled the water onto the baby.  The cook sprinkled on a dusting of powdered sugar.

to squirt out of someone or something; to erupt in a stream out of someone or something.  Hot lava spurted out of the volcano.  Hot lava spurted out from the volcano. The blood spurted out from Walter where he had been slashed.  Blood spurted from the wound.  The fountain had a carved fish with water spurting from its mouth.

The blood spurted out from Walter where he had been slashed.  Blood spurted from the wound.  The fountain had a carved fish with water spurting from its mouth.
to press or mash something into something.  She squashed the clay into the mold. She squashed in the clay and started to make a bowl.

dictionary.phrase: The squeaking wheel gets the oil.
dictionary.definition: Prov. People who complain the most will get attention or what they want.  If you don’t get good service at the hotel, make sure to tell the manager that you’re dissatisfied. The squeaking wheel gets the oil.

dictionary.phrase: The squeaky wheel gets the oil.

dictionary.phrase: squeeze someone or something into something
dictionary.definition: to press or push someone or something into something small.  Let’s see if we can squeeze everyone into the car.  Let’s squeeze in one more.
to press or push someone or something into something small.  Let’s see if we can squeeze everyone into the car.  Let’s squeeze in one more.
to press something until something is expelled from something. Claire squeezed some toothpaste out of the tube.  She squeezed out some toothpaste.
to press something until something is expelled from something. Claire squeezed some toothpaste out of the tube.  She squeezed out some toothpaste.
to cause something to spurt out of something.  He squirted a bit of the vaccine out of the syringe, making sure the needle was not clogged.  He squirted out a bit of the vaccine.
to cause something to spurt out of something.  He squirted a bit of the vaccine out of the syringe, making sure the needle was not clogged.  He squirted out a bit of the vaccine.

dictionary.phrase: stack the deck (against someone or something)
dictionary.definition: to arrange things against someone or something. (Originally from card playing; stacking the deck is to cheat by arranging the cards to be dealt out to one’s advantage.) _ I can’t get ahead at my office. Someone has stacked the cards against me. Do you really think that someone has stacked the deck? Isn’t it just fate?

dictionary.phrase: stack the cards (against someone or something)

Do you really think that someone has stacked the deck? Isn’t it just fate?

dictionary.phrase: stake out a claim to something
dictionary.definition: to lay claim to something. The prospector staked out a claim to the promising piece of land.  We staked out a claim on two seats at the side of the auditorium.

dictionary.phrase: stake out a claim on something
dictionary.definition: to lay claim to something. The prospector staked out a claim to the promising piece of land.  We staked out a claim on two seats at the side of the auditorium.

dictionary.phrase: stamp something out of someone or something
dictionary.definition: to eliminate a characteristic of someone or something; to destroy a characteristic of someone or something.  I would really like to stamp that mean streak out of you.  We were not able to stamp the excess costs out of the proposal and had to reject it. We couldn’t stamp out their bad behavior.

dictionary.phrase: stand (in) back of someone or something
dictionary.definition: to place oneself at the rear of someone or something.  Please stand behind your friends.  The police told them to stand behind the fence.
to place oneself at the rear of someone or something.  Please stand behind your friends.  The police told them to stand behind the fence.

to stand up for one’s rights; to resist an attack.  The lawyer tried to confuse me when I was giving testimony, but I managed to stand my ground.  Some people were trying to crowd us out of the line for tickets, but we held our ground.

to stand up for one’s rights; to resist an attack.  The lawyer tried to confuse me when I was giving testimony, but I managed to stand my ground.  Some people were trying to crowd us out of the line for tickets, but we held our ground.

dictionary.phrase: start off on the wrong foot
dictionary.definition: to begin things incorrectly. (As if one were beginning to march and began on the right rather than the left foot.) _ Give me some advice. I don’t want to start off on the wrong foot. Tim stepped off on the wrong foot in his new job.

dictionary.phrase: step off on the wrong foot
dictionary.definition: to begin things incorrectly. (As if one were beginning to march and began on the right rather than the left foot.) _ Give me some advice. I don’t want to start off on the wrong foot. Tim stepped off on the wrong foot in his new job.

to start out again afresh; to ignore the past and start over again.  I plowed under all last year’s f lowers so I could start with a clean slate next spring. If I start off with a clean slate, then I’ll know exactly what each plant is.  When Bob got out of jail, he started over with a clean slate.

to start someone on a job as a certain kind of worker. I got a job in a restaurant today. They started me in as a dishwasher. I now work for the telephone company. They started me out as a local operator.

to start someone on a job as a certain kind of worker. I got a job in a restaurant today. They started me in as a dishwasher. I now work for the telephone company. They started me out as a local operator.

dictionary.phrase: starve someone or an animal out of some place
dictionary.definition: to force a living creature to come out of a hiding place or a place of security by starvation. The attackers tried to starve the people out of the walled city.  We tried to starve out the mice.

dictionary.phrase: starve someone or an animal out†

to give the best performance in a show, play, or some other event; to get attention for oneself.  The lead in the play was very good, but the butler stole the show.  Ann always tries to steal the spotlight when she and I make a presentation.

to loosen and remove something by an application of steam. (Of is usually retained before pronouns.) _ Toby steamed the old paper off the wall.  Toby steamed off the old wallpaper.

to remove something embedded, through an application of steam.  The cleaner was not able to steam the wrinkles out of my jacket.  I tried to steam out the gum.

to step down onto someone’s toes, causing pain.  Please don’t step on my toes as you walk by.

to hurry up; to make a vehicle go faster. (As if stepping on an automobile’s accelerator.  Step on the gas. We are going to be late! _ Step on it! Let’s go!

to support someone or something; to continue supporting or committing to someone or something when things are bad.  Don’t worry. I’ll stick by you no matter what.  I feel as if I have to stick by my brother even if he goes to jail.

dictionary.phrase: stick something into someone or something

dictionary.phrase: stick something on(to) someone or something
dictionary.definition: to affix something onto someone or something.  The baggage clerk stuck a label onto Jimmy as a joke.  Jimmy stuck on the label.
to affix something onto someone or something.  The baggage clerk stuck a label onto Jimmy as a joke.  Jimmy stuck on the label.
to smell very bad.  What happened? This place stinks to high heaven.  This meat smells to high heaven. Throw it away!

to mix something into something. The painter stirred too much red pigment into the paint. The painter stirred in the pigment.

to sew something onto the surface of something else.  Fred stitched the badge onto his jacket.  Fred stitched on the badge.

absolutely sober. I am stone-cold sober, or I will be by morning anyway.  I found the secret to waking up cold sober. Don’t drink.

an informer. (Originally underworld.) _ Some stool pigeon spilled the works to the boys in blue.  There’s nothing I hate worse than a stoolie.

to visit some place, usually briefly.  I was coming home, but I decided to stop by my aunt’s on the way.  She was very glad that I stopped in.

Inf. Stop everything!; Hold it! (Presses refers to the printing presses used to print newspapers. This means that there is recent news of such magnitude that the presses must be stopped so a new edition can be printed immediately.) _ John (entering the room): Stop the music! There’s a fire in the kitchen! Mary: Good grief! Let’s get out of here! _“Stop the presses!” shouted Jane. “I have an announcement.”

a series of events that are only bad luck.  After a long string of bad luck, we finally got a lucky break.

to find a compromise position; to arrive at a position halfway between two unacceptable extremes. Ann likes very spicy food, but Bob doesn’t care for spicy food at all. We are trying to find a restaurant that strikes a happy medium. Tom is either very happy or very sad. He can’t seem to hit a happy medium.

dictionary.phrase: strip someone or something down to something
dictionary.definition: to remove the covering of someone or something down to the lowest level.  The emergency room nurse stripped the unconscious patient down to his shorts.  He stripped down the patient to his underwear.  He stripped the patient down.

dictionary.phrase: strip something off (of) someone or something
dictionary.definition: to tear something from someone or something. (Of is usually retained before pronouns.) _ The paramedic stripped the shirt off the burn victim and began to treat her burns.  The medic stripped off the patient’s shirt.

Cliché [of a living creature] very strong. (*Also: as ~.) _ Jill: My car broke down; it’s sitting out on the street. Jane: Get Linda to help you push it; she’s as strong as a horse.  The athlete was strong as an ox; he could lift his own weight with just one hand.  The football player was strong as a lion.

dictionary.phrase: stuff someone or something into someone or something
dictionary.definition: to force someone or something into someone or something.  The sheriff stuffed Tex into the tiny cell.  He stuffed in some other prisoners, too.  Donna got down her suitcase and stuffed her clothes in.  The nurse stuffed the oatmeal into the old man faster than he could swallow it.

dictionary.phrase: suck someone or something into something

Inf. And what does it matter if I do? What are you going to do about it? _ Alice: Do you really think it’s right to do something like that? Sue: Suppose I do? _ Fred: Are you going to drive up into the mountains as you said you would? Sally: Supposing I do? Fred: I’m just asking.

Inf. And what does it matter if I do? What are you going to do about it? _ Alice: Do you really think it’s right to do something like that? Sue: Suppose I do? _ Fred: Are you going to drive up into the mountains as you said you would? Sally: Supposing I do? Fred: I’m just asking.

Inf. And what will happen if I don’t? (Said as a sort of threat. Not usually with question intonation.) _ Bill: You’d better get yourself over to the main office. Tom: Suppose I don’t? _ Father: You simply must do better in school. Tom: Supposing I don’t? Father: Your clothing and personal belongings will be placed on the curb for the garbage pickup, and we will have the locks changed. Next question.

dictionary.phrase: swear on a stack of Bibles
dictionary.definition: to state something very earnestly, pledging to tell the truth. Of course, I’m telling the truth. I swear on my mother’s grave!

to arrive suddenly from some place.  Tom just swept in from his vacation to face a pile of work on his desk.  Max breezed in from Vegas and asked about Lefty.
to knock someone down.  The wind swept me off my feet. Bill punched Bob playfully, and knocked him off his feet.
to knock someone down.  The wind swept me off my feet. Bill punched Bob playfully, and knocked him off his feet.
to place someone into an elective position decisively.  The decisive victory swept all the candidates of the reform party into office.  The victory swept in the candidates.
to place someone into an elective position decisively.  The decisive victory swept all the candidates of the reform party into office.  The victory swept in the candidates.

dictionary.phrase: sweep someone or something out of something
dictionary.definition: to remove or brush someone or something from something or some place.  The voters swept the crooks out of office.  We swept out the dirt.
to remove or brush someone or something from something or some place.  The voters swept the crooks out of office.  We swept out the dirt.
to move something into something or some place by sweeping. Liz swept the crumbs into the dish. Liz held the dish and swept in the crumbs.
to move something into something or some place by sweeping. Liz swept the crumbs into the dish. Liz held the dish and swept in the crumbs.
to remove something by sweeping. (Of is usually retained before pronouns.) _The waiter swept the crumbs off the tablecloth.  He swept off the crumbs.
to remove something by sweeping. (Of is usually retained before pronouns.) _The waiter swept the crumbs off the tablecloth.  He swept off the crumbs.

very sweet; charming. (*Also: as ~.) _Larry’s words were sweeter than honey as he tried to convince Alice to forgive him.  Jill: Is Mary Ann nice? Jane: Yes, indeed. She’s as sweet as honey.  Your little girl is darling! Just as sweet as sugar.

a private agreement reached between a public agency or government official and a private company that includes illicit payments or special favors.  They found that the mayor was involved in a number of sweetheart agreements. Most of the building contractors in town would be out of business if they didn’t have sweetheart deals with the local politicians.

very fast. (*Also: as ~.) _ The new intercity train is swift as an arrow.  You won’t have to wait for me long; I’ll be there, swift as thought.
very fast. (*Also: as ~.) _ The new intercity train is swift as an arrow.  You won’t have to wait for me long; I’ll be there, swift as thought.

to swim in a direction opposite to the flow of the water.  She became exhausted, swimming against the tide.  If you really want strenuous exercise, go out in the stream and swim against the current.

to cheat someone out of something.  The crooks tried to swindle her out of her inheritance.  The crooks swindled $3,000 out of the old woman.
to cheat someone out of something.  The crooks tried to swindle her out of her inheritance.  The crooks swindled $3,000 out of the old woman.

dictionary.phrase: swish something off (of) someone or something
dictionary.definition: to brush something off someone or something. (Of is usually retained before pronouns.) _ The barber swished the loose hairs off of Paul’s collar. The barber swished off the loose hairs.
to brush something off someone or something. (Of is usually retained before pronouns.) _ The barber swished the loose hairs off of Paul’s collar. The barber swished off the loose hairs.
to add something onto something.  The waiter kept tacking charges onto my bill. He tacked on charge after charge.
to add something onto something.  The waiter kept tacking charges onto my bill. He tacked on charge after charge.
to follow along after someone; to go along with someone. The family dog tagged along after the children wherever they went.  Can I tag along? _ Do you mind if I tag along behind you?
to follow along after someone; to go along with someone. The family dog tagged along after the children wherever they went.  Can I tag along? _ Do you mind if I tag along behind you?
to have a short rest period in one’s work.  It’s ten o’clock—time to take a break.  I don’t usually take my break until 10:30.
to have a short rest period in one’s work.  It’s ten o’clock—time to take a break.  I don’t usually take my break until 10:30.
to try something where failure or bad fortune is likely.  Come on, take a chance. You may lose, but it’s worth trying.  I’m not reckless, but I don’t mind taking a risk now and then.

to insult or pester someone.  Why did you take a jab at Sam? _ You’re always taking digs at people who think they’re your friends. Jane is always taking digs at Bob, but she never really means any harm.

to fake being knocked out in a boxing match.  Wilbur wouldn’t take a fall. He doesn’t have it in him. The boxer took a dive in the second round and made everyone suspicious.

dictionary.phrase: take a fancy to someone or something
dictionary.definition: to develop a fondness or a preference for someone or something.  John began to take a fancy to Sally late last August at the picnic.  I’ve never taken a liking to cooked carrots.  I think my teacher has taken a shine to me.

to guess.  Even if you don’t know, please take a guess.  If you don’t know the answer, hazard a guess.

1. Fig. to go on a hike; to do hiking.  It’s a beautiful day. Let’s take a hike in the woods.  We took a hike through the forest to visit John’s cabin. 2. Fig. to leave; to beat it.  Okay, I’ve had it with you. Take a hike! Beat it! _ I had enough of the boss and the whole place, so I cleaned out my desk and took a walk.

dictionary.phrase: take a leaf out of someone’s book
dictionary.definition: to behave or to do something in a way that someone else would.  When you act like that, you’re taking a leaf out of your sister’s book, and I don’t like it! _ You had better do it your way. Don’t take a leaf out of my book. I don’t do it well.

dictionary.phrase: take a page from someone’s book
dictionary.definition: to behave or to do something in a way that someone else would.  When you act like that, you’re taking a leaf out of your sister’s book, and I don’t like it! _ You had better do it your way. Don’t take a leaf out of my book. I don’t do it well.

dictionary.phrase: take a load off (of) someone’s mind
dictionary.definition: to relieve one’s mind of a problem or a worry. (Of is usually retained before pronouns.) _I’m glad to hear that. It sure takes a load off of my mind.  This will take a load off her mind.

dictionary.phrase: take a lot off (of) someone’s mind
dictionary.definition: to relieve one’s mind of a problem or a worry. (Of is usually retained before pronouns.) _I’m glad to hear that. It sure takes a load off of my mind.  This will take a load off her mind.

dictionary.phrase: Take a long walk off a short pier.
dictionary.definition: Inf. Get out of here!; Go do something that will get you permanently out of here! _ Get out of here! Take a long walk off a short pier! _You bother me. Go play in the traffic.
Inf. Get out of here!; Go do something that will get you permanently out of here! _ Get out of here! Take a long walk off a short pier! _You bother me. Go play in the traffic.

dictionary.phrase: take a look at someone or something
dictionary.definition: to observe or examine someone or something.  I asked the doctor to take a look at my cut.  Would you please have another look at your work? It is not complete.

dictionary.phrase: have a look at someone or something
dictionary.definition: to observe or examine someone or something.  I asked the doctor to take a look at my cut.  Would you please have another look at your work? It is not complete.

dictionary.phrase: take a look for someone or something
dictionary.definition: to make a visual search for someone or something; to look for someone or something.  Please go to the library and have a look for a book about snakes.  Take a look for a man in a black suit. He is your guide.

dictionary.phrase: have a look for someone or something
dictionary.definition: to make a visual search for someone or something; to look for someone or something.  Please go to the library and have a look for a book about snakes.  Take a look for a man in a black suit. He is your guide.
to punch at someone. Willie took a pop at me, but I ducked.  The drunk took a poke at the cop—which was the wrong thing to do.
to punch at someone. Willie took a pop at me, but I ducked.  The drunk took a poke at the cop—which was the wrong thing to do.
to bathe.  I take a shower every morning.  John takes a hot bath to relax.
to bathe.  I take a shower every morning.  John takes a hot bath to relax.
to take care of oneself.  Mike, like everybody else, is most concerned with taking care of number one. If you don’t take care of numero uno, who will?

to stand up to something adverse, such as criticism. (Fig. on taking a direct punch to the head in boxing.) _They laid some blunt criticism on him, but he took it on the chin.  I knew he could take it on the nose.

dictionary.phrase: take liberties with someone or something
dictionary.definition: to freely use or abuse someone or something. You are overly familiar with me, Mr. Jones. One might think you were taking liberties with me. I don’t like it when you make free with my lawn mower. You should at least ask when you want to borrow it.

to pay no attention to someone; not to believe or accept something.  I take no stock in anything John has to say.  He doesn’t take stock in your opinions either.

not to appear at one’s place of work for a period of time, hours or days. (Often used of an excused or planned absence.) _ I will have to take off from work to go to the doctor. I want to take some time off from work and paint the house. Ken took off from work when he was ill.

[for an event] to acquire a new interpretation; [for something] to become more meaningful or more significant.  All these monuments take on a new meaning when you realize the amount of human artistry and skill it took to design and build them.

to tighten one’s belt a bit. (Probably because one has not eaten recently or because one has lost weight.) _ He pulled his belt in a notch and smiled at his success at losing weight.  He took in his belt a notch and wished he had something to eat.

dictionary.phrase: take one’s hands off (of) someone or something
dictionary.definition: to let go of someone or something. (Of is usually retained before pronouns.) _ Get your hands off of me! _ Please take your hands off the cake plate.

to get even with someone.  Linda planned to take revenge against Ellen.  I intend to take revenge on Paul for what he did.  I will not seek revenge.

to become ill.  I took sick with a bad cold last week.  I hope I don’t take ill before final exams.

to startle someone; to surprise someone with something unexpected.  Oh! You took me by surprise because I didn’t hear you come in.  Bill caught his mother by surprise by coming to the door and pretending to be selling something.

dictionary.phrase: take someone down a peg (or two)
dictionary.definition: to reprimand someone who is acting too arrogant.  The teacher’s scolding took Bob down a notch or two.  He was so rude that someone was bound to knock him down a peg or two.
